> (search-for-primes 1001 1019)

1001
1003
1005
1007
1009 *** 3
1011
1013 *** 3
1015
1017
1019 *** 4
Done

> (search-for-primes 10001 10039)

10001
10003
10005
10007 *** 7
10009 *** 6
10011
10013
10015
10017
10019
10021
10023
10025
10027
10029
10031
10033
10035
10037 *** 6
10039 *** 6
Done

> (search-for-primes 100001 100049)

100001
100003 *** 17
100005
100007
100009
100011
100013
100015
100017
100019 *** 18
100021
100023
100025
100027
100029
100031
100033
100035
100037
100039
100041
100043 *** 17
100045
100047
100049 *** 26
Done

> (search-for-primes 1000001 1000049)

1000001
1000003 *** 50
1000005
1000007
1000009
1000011
1000013
1000015
1000017
1000019
1000021
1000023
1000025
1000027
1000029
1000031
1000033 *** 50
1000035
1000037 *** 49
1000039 *** 50
1000041
1000043
1000045
1000047
1000049
Done

n=1000, approximately 3 seconds.
n=10000, approximately 6 seconds.
n=100000, approximately 18 seconds.
n=1000000, approximately 50 seconds.

So the next function seems to shave off about a third of the time.  My guess as to why it's not
halved is that incrementing with next takes longer than incrementing by 1 because of the if
statement in the next function.
